title: E15 Momentum: Growth Energy Pushes for Year-Round Sales and Export Growth
description:
E15 Momentum: Growth Energy Pushes for Year-Round Sales and Export Growth: Growth Energy CEO Emily Skor spoke with Farm Director KC Sheperd, highlighting the strong momentum for E15 (a 15% ethanol blend) and the industry’s focus on securing permanent regulatory fixes and expanding global markets.
E15 Growth and Legislative Push The industry is seeing unprecedented momentum, making a push to update a 35-year-old regulation that currently limits year-round sales of the fuel: National Reach: E15 is now legally able to be sold in all 50 states following recent legalization in California.
Retail Expansion: The number of retailers selling E15 has increased by almost 25% this year, the largest growth since 2018.
Legislative Priority: Securing a legislative fix to allow year-round E15 sales nationwide remains a top priority, with conversations ongoing on Capitol Hill and with the White House.
Expanding Global and New Market Opportunities Beyond domestic fuel pumps, the ethanol industry is actively pursuing export and new fuel applications:
text:
E15 Momentum: Growth Energy Pushes for Year-Round Sales and Export Growth:

Growth Energy CEO Emily Skor spoke with Farm Director KC Sheperd, highlighting the strong momentum for E15 (a 15% ethanol blend) and the industry’s focus on securing permanent regulatory fixes and expanding global markets.

E15 Growth and Legislative Push

The industry is seeing unprecedented momentum, making a push to update a 35-year-old regulation that currently limits year-round sales of the fuel:

National Reach: E15 is now legally able to be sold in all 50 states following recent legalization in California.

Retail Expansion: The number of retailers selling E15 has increased by almost 25% this year, the largest growth since 2018.

Legislative Priority: Securing a legislative fix to allow year-round E15 sales nationwide remains a top priority, with conversations ongoing on Capitol Hill and with the White House. This permanent fix would eliminate the current need for the EPA to issue emergency waivers each summer to allow E15 sales due to fuel volatility restrictions known as Reid Vapor Pressure (RVP) limits.

Bipartisan Effort: The push has strong bipartisan support. For instance, the Nationwide Consumer and Fuel Retailer Choice Act has been introduced in Congress to permanently extend the RVP waiver to E15, eliminating seasonal restrictions.

Current Status: While a permanent fix remains the goal, recent legislative attempts, such as including the fix in a broader short-term funding bill, have faced opposition from some House Republicans concerned about the impact on the U.S. refining sector.

Economic and Agricultural Benefits

E15 is being positioned as a solution for both consumer costs and farm oversupply:

Consumer Savings: Higher blends of ethanol make fuel more affordable. Consumers typically save 10 to 30 cents per gallon with E15, with some reports showing savings as high as 80 cents to a dollar.

Corn Demand: If every vehicle drove on a 15% ethanol blend, it would utilize 2.5 billion bushels of U.S. corn every year, providing a vital market for corn producers who are seeing fantastic crops and need a home for their grain.

Political Focus: The two main drivers in Washington supporting the E15 fix are the need to address the state of the farm economy (providing markets, not handouts) and the national attention on consumer prices and the cost of fuel.

Expanding Global and New Market Opportunities

Beyond domestic fuel pumps, the ethanol industry is actively pursuing export and new fuel applications:

title: Qanot Sharq takes delivery of its first Airbus A321XLR aircraft
description:
Hamburg, Germany, 19 December 2025 – Qanot Sharq, one of Uzbekistan's leading private passenger airlines, has taken delivery of its first of four A321XLR aircraft via a long-term lease agreement with Air Lease (NYSE: AL).
With this delivery, Qanot Sharq becomes the first A321XLR operator in Central Asia and the CIS, reinforcing the airline's ambition to modernise its fleet and expand its international route network and operate new routes to key markets across Asia, including Sanya and Busan, and New York City (via Budapest), while significantly enhancing Qanot Sharq's connectivity across Asia-Pacific and Europe.
It offers passengers and cabin crew the enhanced comfort of Airbus’ Airspace Cabin, featuring XL overhead bins with 60% more storage space compared to previous generation aircraft.
As with all Airbus aircraft, the A321XLR aircraft is already able to operate with up to 50% Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF).
Airbus is targeting to have its aircraft up to 100% SAF capable by 2030.
text:
Hamburg, Germany, 19 December 2025 – Qanot Sharq, one of Uzbekistan's leading private passenger airlines, has taken delivery of its first of four A321XLR aircraft via a long-term lease agreement with Air Lease (NYSE: AL).

With this delivery, Qanot Sharq becomes the first A321XLR operator in Central Asia and the CIS, reinforcing the airline's ambition to modernise its fleet and expand its international route network and operate new routes to key markets across Asia, including Sanya and Busan, and New York City (via Budapest), while significantly enhancing Qanot Sharq's connectivity across Asia-Pacific and Europe.

Powered by CFM LEAP-1A engines, the aircraft is configured with 190 seats in a two-class layout featuring 16 full-flat Business Class and 174 Economy Class seats. It offers passengers and cabin crew the enhanced comfort of Airbus’ Airspace Cabin, featuring XL overhead bins with 60% more storage space compared to previous generation aircraft. In addition, in-seat connectivity is available to all passengers while the latest lighting system enhances the overall passenger experience.

The A321XLR is the next evolutionary step of the A320neo Family, responding to market needs for more range and payload, creating even more value for the airlines. It will deliver an unprecedented Xtra Long Range of up to 4,700nm, some 15% more range than the A321LR and 30% lower fuel burn per seat compared with previous generation competitor aircraft, as well as reduced NOx emissions and noise. So far, Airbus has secured more than 500 orders for the type.

As with all Airbus aircraft, the A321XLR aircraft is already able to operate with up to 50% Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF). Airbus is targeting to have its aircraft up to 100% SAF capable by 2030.

title: FedEx revenue up by 14% to $23.5 billion in second quarter - STAT Times
authors: STAT Times, The STAT Trade Times
description:
FedEx announced financial performance for its fiscal second quarter ending November 30, reporting consolidated net revenue of $23.5 billion.
This represents a 14% increase over the $22.0 billion recorded during the same period last year.
The company saw its operating income nearly double, climbing to $1.38 billion from $0.74 billion in the previous year.
The Federal Express division saw improved operating results, benefiting from the same yield and volume trends driving the consolidated growth.
Notably, FedEx Freight incurred $152 million in one-time costs during the quarter specifically related to this spin-off.
text:
FedEx announced financial performance for its fiscal second quarter ending November 30, reporting consolidated net revenue of $23.5 billion. This represents a 14% increase over the $22.0 billion recorded during the same period last year.

The company saw its operating income nearly double, climbing to $1.38 billion from $0.74 billion in the previous year. According to the company, the growth was primarily fueled by higher yields in U.S. domestic and international priority shipping, alongside increased domestic package volumes.

The bottom line also benefited from aggressive cost-saving measures through ongoing transformation initiatives and a reduction in business optimisation expenses.

“I am extremely proud of our team members worldwide for their commitment to make every FedEx experience outstanding this Peak season,” said Raj Subramaniam, FedEx President and CEO,

However, the quarter was not without its challenges. The gains were partially offset by the financial fallout from shifting global trade policies, rising wage rates, and increased variable incentive compensation. FedEx also navigated higher purchased transportation costs and the operational impact of grounding its MD-11 aircraft fleet.

The performance across business segments was mixed. The Federal Express division saw improved operating results, benefiting from the same yield and volume trends driving the consolidated growth. Conversely, the FedEx Freight segment experienced a decline in results.

This dip was attributed to lower shipment volumes and increased expenses related to the hiring of dedicated sales professionals as the company prepares to spin off the unit. Notably, FedEx Freight incurred $152 million in one-time costs during the quarter specifically related to this spin-off.

title: SAF Summit - Global Sustainable Aviation Fuel Summit 2026 (China) - Events
description:
▪️Connecting China & Asia's SAF Supply with Global Demand When: May 28-29, 2026 Where: Shanghai, China Summit Background As the global aviation industry accelerates its transition toward net-zero emissions, Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) has been widely recognised as the most viable and scalable solution for reducing aviation emissions over the coming decades.
Securing compliant, reliable and cost-competitive SAF supply has therefore become a strategic priority for airlines worldwide.
At the same time, China and the wider Asia-Pacific region are rapidly emerging as key growth engines of the global SAF industry.
Against this backdrop, the Global Sustainable Aviation Fuel Summit – China Chapter has been established as a project-driven collaboration platform for the global aviation and SAF community.
Register now to secure your pass to co-define the future of sustainable aviation with global industry leaders.
text:
▪️Connecting China & Asia's SAF Supply with Global Demand

When: May 28-29, 2026

Where: Shanghai, China

Summit Background

As the global aviation industry accelerates its transition toward net-zero emissions, Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) has been widely recognised as the most viable and scalable solution for reducing aviation emissions over the coming decades. With regulatory frameworks such as the EU ReFuelEU Aviation initiative and ICAO’s CORSIA being progressively implemented, airlines are facing increasingly clear and binding SAF adoption requirements. Securing compliant, reliable and cost-competitive SAF supply has therefore become a strategic priority for airlines worldwide.

At the same time, China and the wider Asia-Pacific region are rapidly emerging as key growth engines of the global SAF industry. With long-term advantages in feedstock availability, industrial capacity, engineering expertise and manufacturing scale, China is accelerating the development of SAF pilot projects and commercial deployment. As production pathways mature and certification systems increasingly align with international standards, China’s SAF industry is well positioned not only to meet domestic demand, but also to integrate into global aviation fuel supply chains as an important source of diversified SAF supply for international airlines.

Against this backdrop, the Global Sustainable Aviation Fuel Summit – China Chapter has been established as a project-driven collaboration platform for the global aviation and SAF community. The summit brings together policymakers, airlines, SAF producers, technology providers, feedstock suppliers, financial institutions and certification bodies to engage in in-depth discussions on policy alignment, supply network development, commercial models, investment mechanisms and future technology pathways. By connecting China and Asia-Pacific’s SAF capabilities with the practical needs of global airlines, the summit aims to foster cross-regional collaboration, accelerate the transition from pilot projects to large-scale deployment, and deliver actionable solutions to support the long-term decarbonisation of the global aviation industry.

Agenda Topics Include

1, China’s SAF Landscape: Current Development Stage and Outlook

2, Global SAF Blueprint: Regional Policies, Regulation and Alignment

3, Building the Global SAF Supply Network: Partnerships, Logistics & Market Access

4, Market Insight: Latest Developments in e-SAF

5, From First Projects to Scale: Reducing Cost and Risk through Industry Collaboration

6, Financing SAF: Investment Structures, Risk Allocation & Bankability

7, Feedstock Carbon Intensity and Supply Chain Sustainability: Opportunities and Challenges

8, Building the e-SAF Ecosystem: Opportunities, Challenges & Timelines

......

Who Should Attend

- Airlines and aviation groups

- SAF production, technology and project development enterprises

- Raw material supply and logistics enterprises

- Airport operation and infrastructure parties

- Representatives from policy and regulatory authorities

- Investment institutions, banks and financial service providers

- Certification bodies and research institutions

Why is it worth participating in this summit?

▪️ Track global policy trends and anchor compliance pathways

▪️ Connect with Asia-Pacific supply resources and explore supply cooperation opportunities

▪️ Listen to airlines’ demands and achieve accurate market matching

▪️ Gain insights into technology evolution pathways and build future competitiveness

▪️ Explore business model and financing innovations to drive project implementation

▪️ Integrate into the global SAF ecosystem and establish long-term partnerships

Early Bird Discounts Now Available – Limited Seats Only!

Register now to secure your pass to co-define the future of sustainable aviation with global industry leaders.

For more information, visit the official website:

https://www.ecv-events.com/GSAFS2026?cci=45

title: Airlines, Par Hawaii, Pono Energy partner to advance local SAF supply chain
description:
Hawaiian Airlines announced Dec. 17 that it and Alaska Airlines have joined Par Hawaii to invest in pioneering the development of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Hawaii using locally grown agriculture feedstock to reduce aviation-carbon emissions.
The combined airlines also will become Par Hawaii’s launch SAF customer, with plans to take delivery of Hawaii’s first locally produced SAF in the first quarter of 2026.
“Our company has a long-term strategy to reach net-zero carbon emissions, and sustainable aviation fuel is essential for us to get there.
The initial investment allowed Pono Pacific to conduct crop trials on four islands, in partnership with Aloun Farms, Mahi Pono and Meadow Gold Dairy.
As Pono Pacific advances the agricultural foundation for camelina, Par Hawaii, the state’s largest fuels manufacturer, is preparing to deliver SAF in the first quarter of 2026.
text:
Hawaiian Airlines announced Dec. 17 that it and Alaska Airlines have joined Par Hawaii to invest in pioneering the development of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Hawaii using locally grown agriculture feedstock to reduce aviation-carbon emissions.

This initiative will enable SAF production for more sustainable future flying and deliver economic benefits through the creation of a new energy sector and fuel supply chain in Hawaii, while bringing new opportunities for local agriculture.

Hawaiian Airlines and Alaska Airlines, which together provide the most flights to, from and within Hawaii, and Par Hawaii, the largest producer of energy products in the islands, are partnering with Pono Pacific through its Pono Energy subsidiary, to study camelina as a multipurpose crop that can be used as SAF feedstock and to support agriculture.

The combined airlines also will become Par Hawaii’s launch SAF customer, with plans to take delivery of Hawaii’s first locally produced SAF in the first quarter of 2026.

SAF, a safe drop-in fuel made from sustainable feedstock such as plant-based oils or used cooking oil, can cut lifecycle-carbon emissions by up to 80 percent compared to conventional jet fuel.

Pono Pacific’s crop trials drew the attention of Alaska Star Ventures, the venture capital arm of Alaska Air Group that invests in technologies to drive aviation efficiency, performance and innovation.

“As Hawaii’s airline, we have a responsibility to reduce our environmental impact while continuing to provide essential air service that connects our communities and strengthens our economy,” said Alanna James, the sustainability innovation director for Hawaiian Airlines and Alaska Airlines. “Our company has a long-term strategy to reach net-zero carbon emissions, and sustainable aviation fuel is essential for us to get there. We are grateful to have partners like Par Hawaii and Pono Pacific who share our commitment to making our operations more sustainable while creating a new fuel industry and strengthening Hawaii’s energy independence.”

Ed Sniffen, the director of Hawaii’s state department of transportation, said, “We value the efforts of our airline partners as we work together to find long-term solutions to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions and increase our energy security, while meeting Hawaii’s transportation needs. We applaud Hawaiian and Alaska airlines, Par Hawaii and Pono Pacific for taking this important step to establish a locally based, lower-emissions supply chain for aviation fuel that supports our state’s clean-energy goals.”

Pono Pacific, the state’s largest private-resource company, will launch Pono Energy Inc. in early 2026 to accelerate its work on camelina, a high-yield, pest-resistant cover crop that can be grown in rotation with food crops, reaching maturity in just eight to nine weeks.

Its oilseeds can be crushed to produce renewable fuels, including SAF, while the remaining seedcake can be turned into government-approved, nutrient-rich feed for cattle and chickens.

This revenue-generating cover crop will deliver more economic opportunity for Hawaii by creating jobs, supporting farmers and decreasing the aviation industry’s carbon footprint.

“Camelina represents a rare opportunity for Hawaii to build a true circular-economy model around renewable fuels,” said Chris Bennett, the vice president of sustainable energy solutions for Pono Pacific Land Management LLC. “By growing this crop locally, we strengthen our agricultural sector, keep more dollars circulating within the state and reduce our dependence on imported fossil fuels. Camelina can be refined into sustainable aviation fuel while the remaining seedcake becomes a valuable, locally produced animal feed that supports Hawaii’s ranchers and livestock industry. We will explore food crops that can be grown alongside camelina to increase food security as well. It’s a win for our economy, a win for local agriculture and a win for the environment—an example of how Hawaii can lead the way in innovative, homegrown climate solutions.”

Alaska Star Ventures has made a new investment that builds on Par Hawaii’s earlier support of Pono Pacific, which collaborated with the Hawaii Agriculture Research Center to begin cultivating 50 non-GMO camelina varieties in 2023 to identify those best suited to Hawaii’s year-round temperate climate.

The initial investment allowed Pono Pacific to conduct crop trials on four islands, in partnership with Aloun Farms, Mahi Pono and Meadow Gold Dairy.

Pono Pacific identified suitable agricultural lands across the state and engaged Hawaii’s cattle and livestock industry to explore the use of camelina seedcake as animal feed.

As Pono Pacific advances the agricultural foundation for camelina, Par Hawaii, the state’s largest fuels manufacturer, is preparing to deliver SAF in the first quarter of 2026.

Earlier this year, Par Pacific, the parent company of Par Hawaii, formed Hawaii Renewables and partnered with Alohi Renewable Energy LLC, a joint venture between Mitsubishi and Eneos, following a $100 million investment to convert and upgrade one of the refinery’s processing units into a renewable hydrotreater capable of processing plant-based and waste oils.

“In 2022, when we formed an agreement with Hawaiian Airlines to jointly study the commercial viability of locally produced sustainable aviation fuels, we didn’t think we would be able to progress so quickly,” said Eric Wright, the president of Par Hawaii. “With renewable fuel production coming online in early 2026, it’s exciting to see the results of our team’s hard work. These fuels will have up to 80 percent lower carbon emissions compared to conventional fuels. This would not have been possible without a shared vision for our islands and our great teamwork.”

James added, “We are thrilled to be the first customer to receive SAF from Par Hawaii next year. This is an important milestone for our company and Hawaii, but there is still more work to do. While SAF is the best option to reduce aviation emissions, it is two to three times more expensive than regular jet fuel and supply is limited. We will need strong collaboration across airlines, fuel and feedstock producers, investors, including business partners seeking to offset their scope 3 emissions, and government, along with supportive policies, to grow the SAF industry and reach our decarbonization goals.”

title: IATA flags slowdown in sustainable aviation fuel production - BW Hotelier
description:
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has reported a slowdown in the growth of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production, warning that policy frameworks need urgent correction ahead of upcoming e-SAF mandates.
At current prices, the SAF premium is estimated to add USD 3.6 billion to industry fuel costs in 2025.
“SAF production growth fell short of expectations as poorly designed mandates stalled momentum in the fledgling SAF industry.
If the goal of SAF mandates was to slow progress and increase prices, policymakers knocked it out of the park.
“Given the low SAF production volumes, it is evident that current policies are not having the desired effect.
text:
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has reported a slowdown in the growth of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production, warning that policy frameworks need urgent correction ahead of upcoming e-SAF mandates.

According to IATA’s latest estimates, global SAF production is expected to reach 1.9 million tonnes in 2025, doubling from 2024 levels. However, growth is projected to slow in 2026, with output rising to only 2.4 million tonnes. SAF will account for just 0.6 per cent of total jet fuel consumption in 2025, increasing marginally to 0.8 per cent in 2026. At current prices, the SAF premium is estimated to add USD 3.6 billion to industry fuel costs in 2025.

IATA said the 2025 forecast represents a downward revision due to limited policy support and high costs. In mandated markets, SAF prices can reach up to five times that of conventional jet fuel.

“SAF production growth fell short of expectations as poorly designed mandates stalled momentum in the fledgling SAF industry. If the goal of SAF mandates was to slow progress and increase prices, policymakers knocked it out of the park. But if the objective is to increase SAF production to further. The decarbonisation of aviation, then they need to learn from failure and work with the airline industry to design incentives that will work,” said Willie Walsh, IATA’s Director General.

IATA highlighted that EU and UK mandates have increased costs without ensuring adequate supply. Airlines paid an estimated $2.9 billion premium for limited SAF volumes in 2025.

Looking ahead, IATA cautioned that without strong incentives, upcoming e-SAF mandates in the UK and EU could further raise costs and limit supply.

“Given the low SAF production volumes, it is evident that current policies are not having the desired effect. Faced with such facts, regulators must course-correct, ensure the long-term viability of SAF production, and achieve scale so that costs can come down. Mandates have done just the opposite, and it is outrageous to repeat the same mistakes with e-SAF mandates,” said Marie Owens Thomsen, IATA’s Senior Vice President for Sustainability and Chief Economist.

title: Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil Market Size, Share & Growth Report by 2034
description:

By Product Type, the Sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) segment is estimated to register the fastest CAGR growth of 9.0%.
Market Drivers Regulatory Support and Government Incentives Strong regulatory support is a key driver of the HVO market.
Latin America Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil Market Insights Latin America shows steady HVO market growth supported by industrial expansion, rising transport demand, and favorable renewable energy policies.
Competitive Landscape The hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) market is moderately fragmented, characterized by a mix of legacy energy majors, diversified renewables specialists, and emerging regional producers.
text:
Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil Market Overview

The global hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) market size is valued at USD 8.25 billion in 2025 and is projected to reach USD 15.77 billion by 2034, growing at a CAGR of 7.5% during the forecast period. The market growth is primarily driven by increasing demand for renewable and low-carbon fuels, technological advancements in hydrogenation processes, and supportive government policies aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the transportation and industrial sectors. Rising corporate sustainability commitments, along with the growing adoption of HVO in aviation, marine, and heavy-duty vehicles, further accelerate market expansion.

Key Market Trends & Insights

Europe dominated the market with a revenue share of 42% in 2025.

Asia Pacific is anticipated to grow at the fastest CAGR of 8.5% during the forecast period.

Based on Feedstock, the Waste and residue oils segment held the highest market share of 45% in 2025.

By Product Type, the Sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) segment is estimated to register the fastest CAGR growth of 9.0%.

Based on Application, the Road Transport category dominated the market in 2025 with a revenue share of 50%.

Based on Distribution Channel, the B2B contracts for industrial power generation and marine fuelsegment is projected to register the fastest CAGR of 8.1% during the forecast period.

Germany dominates the market, valued at USD 1,302.00 million in 2024 and reaching USD 1,378.43 million in 2025.

Germany Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil Market Size (USD Million)

Source: Straits Research

Market Revenue Figures

2025 Market Size: USD 8.25 billion

2034 Projected Market Size: USD 15.77 billion

CAGR (2026-2034): 7.5%

Dominating Region: Europe

Fastest-Growing Region: Asia Pacific

The global HVO market encompasses renewable diesel and jet fuel derived from vegetable oils, waste fats, and other bio-based feedstocks. These fuels are primarily used in the transportation sector, including commercial vehicles, aviation, and maritime shipping, and are increasingly used in industrial power generation. HVO serves as a drop-in solution for diesel engines, offering superior performance, reduced emissions, and compatibility with existing infrastructure. Key growth drivers include increasing environmental regulations, growing awareness of carbon reduction initiatives, continuous process innovation, and expanding distribution networks for renewable fuels.

Latest Market Trends

Sustainability-Driven Adoption in Transportation

The global push toward lower-carbon transportation fuels is accelerating the adoption of hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) as a renewable diesel alternative. Governments are tightening carbon emission standards for heavy-duty vehicles while promoting low-emission fuels through incentives and regulations. Fleet operators are increasingly preferring HVO due to its high cetane number, excellent cold-flow performance, and full compatibility with existing diesel engines, without any blending limits. These advantages enable operators to reduce emissions without requiring modifications to their infrastructure or vehicles.

Integration with Circular Economy Initiatives

HVO production is increasingly aligned with circular economy principles through the use of waste-based feedstocks such as used cooking oil and animal fats. This approach reduces dependence on virgin vegetable oils and helps address waste management challenges. Utilising waste materials reduces environmental impact while enhancing long-term feedstock security. This integration supports sustainable fuel production, reduces lifecycle emissions, and enhances market resilience. Circular sourcing strategies also strengthen regulatory acceptance and support broader HVO adoption in regions focused on sustainability goals.

Market Drivers

Regulatory Support and Government Incentives

Strong regulatory support is a key driver of the HVO market. Governments promote renewable fuels through carbon reduction mandates, tax incentives, and fuel blending requirements. These policies encourage fleet operators, industrial users, and fuel distributors to transition toward low-emission alternatives. Clear regulatory frameworks provide long-term visibility into demand, supporting investment in production capacity and supply infrastructure. As decarbonization targets expand across transportation and industry, regulatory backing continues to play a central role in accelerating HVO adoption and market expansion.

Growing Demand for Low-Emission Fuels in Aviation

HVO is gaining traction as a sustainable aviation fuel due to its ability to significantly reduce lifecycle carbon emissions compared to conventional jet fuel. Airlines are increasingly adopting sustainable fuels to meet environmental commitments, regulatory requirements, and corporate sustainability targets. Growing pressure to decarbonise air travel is encouraging airlines and fuel suppliers to expand the use of sustainable fuels. This trend supports increased production capacity and positions HVO as a key contributor to decarbonising the aviation sector.

Market Restraint

Feedstock Availability Constraints

Limited availability of sustainable feedstocks presents a challenge to scaling HVO production. Waste oils, animal fats, and non-food crops are in finite supply and face competition from food, chemical, and other biofuel industries. Supply constraints can increase feedstock prices and create uncertainty for producers planning capacity expansion. Geographic imbalance in feedstock availability further complicates supply chains. These limitations can restrict production growth and delay the initiation of new projects.

Market Opportunity

Expansion in Emerging Markets

Emerging economies in the Asia Pacific and Latin America present strong growth opportunities for the HVO market, driven by rising demand for transport fuels and an increasing focus on environmental regulations. Local production using regionally available feedstocks can reduce dependence on imported fossil fuels and improve energy security. Growing urbanisation, logistics activity, and public transport expansion further support demand for cleaner fuels. As governments introduce sustainability policies and invest in renewable energy infrastructure, the adoption of HVO is expected to accelerate.

Regional Analysis

Europe dominated the market in 2025, accounting for 42% market share, supported by strong environmental regulations, carbon reduction targets, and widespread adoption of renewable fuels. Sustainability mandates, carbon pricing mechanisms, and low-carbon fuel standards encourage the use of HVO across transportation, industrial, and aviation sectors. The region benefits from a mature production ecosystem, advanced hydrogenation technologies, and efficient fuel distribution networks. Investments in feedstock collection, refinery upgrades, and fuel blending infrastructure further strengthen supply stability.

Germany is the leading national market in Europe, driven by stringent climate policies, low-emission transport regulations, and strong adoption by commercial fleets and logistics operators. Government incentives and urban low-emission zones encourage fleet conversion, while close collaboration between refiners, feedstock suppliers, and transport companies ensures supply reliability. Germany’s advanced industrial base and sustainability focus position it as a key driver of HVO demand in Europe.

Asia Pacific Market Insights

Asia Pacific is emerging as the fastest-growing region with a CAGR of 8.5% from 2026-2034, driven by rapid urbanisation, industrial expansion, and rising fuel demand in transportation and aviation. Governments across the region promote renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel through policy support, incentives, and clean energy targets. The availability of agricultural feedstocks such as palm, soybean, and rapeseed oil enables cost-efficient production. The expansion of public transport systems, growth in logistics, and airline decarbonization efforts further support the adoption. Partnerships between global producers and local distributors improve market access, making Asia Pacific a key growth region for HVO.

China is the primary growth engine in Asia Pacific due to high fuel consumption, expanding logistics networks, and strong government backing for low-carbon energy. Renewable diesel is increasingly adopted in industrial fleets, shipping, and aviation. Policies promoting green transport and carbon reduction accelerate market uptake, while digital fuel platforms and centralized procurement improve access for regional fleet operators.

Source: Straits Research

North America Market Insights

North America represents a high-value market supported by strong fleet adoption and well-defined low-carbon fuel regulations. Renewable fuel standards and regional blending mandates encourage the use of HVO in heavy-duty transport, aviation, and industrial power generation. The region benefits from advanced logistics infrastructure, large-scale refining capacity, and long-term supply agreements between producers and fleet operators. Stable policy frameworks and high fuel consumption levels make North America a mature yet expanding market for renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel.

The U.S. is the largest HVO market in North America, driven by emissions regulations, carbon intensity targets, and widespread adoption of fleet electrification alternatives. Renewable diesel is increasingly used in logistics, public transport, and aviation. Long-term supply contracts with industrial users and transport operators ensure stable demand, while the adoption of sustainable aviation fuel by airlines strengthens market growth.

Latin America Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil Market Insights

Latin America shows steady HVO market growth supported by industrial expansion, rising transport demand, and favorable renewable energy policies. Countries across the region promote sustainable fuels through blending mandates, fiscal incentives, and decarbonization strategies. A strong agricultural base provides abundant feedstocks such as soybean and palm oil, enabling cost-effective production. Growing urban logistics activity, fleet modernization, and aviation sector expansion support rising consumption.

Brazil leads the Latin American market due to its established biofuel industry and abundant agricultural feedstock supply. Renewable diesel adoption is supported by blending mandates, sustainable aviation initiatives, and transport sector modernisation. Direct supply agreements with logistics and industrial operators ensure consistent demand.

Middle East and Africa (MEA) Market Insights

The Middle East and Africa HVO market is developing steadily, driven by fuel diversification strategies, transport modernisation, and sustainability initiatives in key economies. Gulf countries are leading the adoption due to high fuel consumption, advanced infrastructure, and growing interest in renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel. Access to major ports, logistics hubs, and regional trade routes supports scalable deployment.

The UAE is the leading HVO market in MEA, supported by sustainability policies, high transport fuel demand, and aviation sector growth. Renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel adoption is expanding through partnerships with global producers. Strong storage, blending, and distribution infrastructure enhances market readiness, while incentives for low-carbon fuels support fleet adoption.

Feedstock Analysis

Waste and residue oils dominated the market with a revenue share of 45% in 2025. Their popularity stems from low-cost availability, strong environmental credentials, and alignment with circular economy initiatives. Industrial users and commercial fleets prefer waste-derived HVO to meet sustainability targets without competing with food production. Companies investing in collection networks for used cooking oil and animal fats are expanding capacity and reducing feedstock costs, further supporting this subsegment’s dominance.

Vegetable oil-based HVO is the fastest-growing at a CAGR of 8.0%. Rising global demand for renewable diesel and SAF has prompted expansion in the processing of palm, rapeseed, and soybean oil. The segment benefits from stable supply chains in Southeast Asia and Europe, government blending mandates, and premium pricing for certified sustainable feedstocks, which drive consistent adoption in both the transportation and aviation sectors.

Product Type Insights

Renewable diesel holds the largest market share of 60% in 2025. Its compatibility with existing diesel engines and infrastructure, along with lower emissions compared to conventional diesel, makes it the most widely used HVO product. Commercial fleet operators, public transport authorities, and logistics companies are increasingly switching to renewable diesel to meet sustainability mandates and reduce carbon taxation burdens.

Sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) is the fastest-growing product type with a CAGR of 9.0%. Airlines and aviation authorities are adopting SAF to comply with the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) and corporate sustainability targets. Technological improvements in HVO-based jet fuel production have increased yields and reduced costs, making it more attractive for commercial aviation.

By Application Market Share (%), 2025

Source: Straits Research

Application Insights

Road transport dominates the market with a 50% share in 2025. HVO is widely used in heavy-duty trucks, buses, and commercial fleets due to its drop-in compatibility with diesel engines and its significant reduction in emissions. Increasing investments in infrastructure and bulk supply agreements enhance accessibility and reliability, consolidating road transport as the primary application segment for HVO globally.

Aviation is the fastest-growing application segment, expected to grow at a CAGR of 9.2% from 2025 to 2034. Airlines are under mounting pressure to reduce carbon footprints and comply with international emission regulations. HVO-derived SAF offers a low-carbon alternative for commercial flights and military aviation. The segment’s growth is fueled by government incentives, corporate ESG mandates, and technological advancements in fuel conversion and distribution networks.

Distribution Channel Insights

Direct supply to fleet operators holds 55% market share in 2025. Industrial users and large transport companies prefer contractual agreements for guaranteed HVO supply, price stability, and logistical support. Long-term contracts enable HVO producers to optimise production planning and maintain consistent revenue streams. Fleet operators benefit from predictable pricing and compliance with sustainability policies, making this the largest distribution channel for HVO globally.

B2B contracts for industrial power generation and marine fuel are growing at a CAGR of 8.1%. Industrial and shipping sectors are increasingly adopting HVO as a low-carbon fuel alternative to heavy fuel oil. The segment’s growth is supported by sustainability mandates, energy security concerns, and the need to reduce emissions in industrial operations.

Competitive Landscape

The hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) market is moderately fragmented, characterized by a mix of legacy energy majors, diversified renewables specialists, and emerging regional producers. Established global players dominate through extensive refining infrastructure, long-term supply agreements with commercial fleets and aviation operators, and robust R&D capabilities focused on process efficiency and feedstock flexibility. Mid-tier and new entrants are competing by developing localized production capacity, leveraging waste and residue feedstock streams, and pursuing sustainability certifications to meet corporate and regulatory decarbonization goals.

SkyNRG: A Sustainable Fuel Innovator

SkyNRG has established itself as an innovative player in the HVO-based sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) segment, focusing on bridging supply with airline demand for low-carbon jet fuels. SkyNRG’s core strengths lie in its sustainability-centric business model, expertise in SAF certification pathways, and ability to structure long-term contracts that de-risk investment for both producers and carriers. It primarily appeals to environmentally conscious commercial and cargo airlines, distinguishing itself through bespoke supply agreements and a strong commitment to transparent lifecycle emissions reporting.

Latest News:

In June 2025, SkyNRG highlighted that supplied SAF volumes doubled in 2024 and demand is projected to reach approximately 2 million tonnes this year, indicating a busy period for securing supply capacity.

Strategic Initiatives

December 2025 - TotalEnergies confirmed that its Grandpuits "Zero-Crude" platform is on track to be commissioned in mid-2025. It will process 400,000 metric tons/year, producing 210,000 tons of SAF and 50,000 tons of HVO.

November 2025 - Enilive, along with PETRONAS and Euglena, held a groundbreaking ceremony for a new biorefinery in Pengerang, Malaysia. The facility will have a capacity of 650,000 tonnes/year of HVO and SAF, targeted to start in 2028.

October 2025 - Neste is currently completing a 2.5 billion Euros investment in its Rotterdam refinery expansion. Once fully ramped up, it will solidify Rotterdam as a global leader in SAF and HVO production.

September 2025 - Shell officially launched its branded Renewable Diesel (HVO) and R33 blend in key global hubs (including Hong Kong and the US). Marketed as "Shell Renewable Diesel," it targets heavy-duty fleets and promises up to 90% CO2e reduction.

Her expertise bridges data analytics with strategic foresight, empowering stakeholders to make informed, growth-oriented decisions.

title: How Delta is Innovating Toward Net Zero | Manufacturing Digital
description:
The Atlanta-based carrier also surpasses its near-term fuel savings objective, delivering in excess of 55 million gallons of jet fuel savings from operational improvements in the first quarter alone.
Fuel efficiency through innovative engineering Elsewhere, Delta strengthens its collaboration with Airbus, testing a flying technique called fello'fly, which is inspired by migrating geese.
The technology can be applied to an aircraft's fuselage, wings and tail and may improve fuel efficiency by up to 4%.
One of Delta’s primary goals for the year is to procure more than 35 sustainable aircraft.
On average, these new planes are over 25% more fuel-efficient per seat mile than the aircraft Delta has retired since 2019.
text:
In its centennial year, Delta Air Lines focuses on progression rather than reflection.

The airline, which was founded in Macon, Georgia, is having one of its most progressive 12 months to date, making considerable progress on its fuel efficiency targets, forming new partnerships to develop aircraft prototypes and reducing the use of unsustainable materials.

The Atlanta-based carrier also surpasses its near-term fuel savings objective, delivering in excess of 55 million gallons of jet fuel savings from operational improvements in the first quarter alone. This achievement results in savings of more than US$125 million and advances its net zero ambitions.

Manufacturing partnerships and aircraft design

In March, Delta announced a partnership with aerospace startup JetZero to support the development of its blended wing-body (BWB) aircraft. This futuristic plane design is anticipated to be up to 50% more fuel efficient than the average aircraft currently in service.

Delta is lending its operational expertise through its Sustainable Skies Lab to help bring the BWB aircraft closer to commercial viability.

Later in September, Delta partners with Maeve Aerospace to expedite the development of hybrid electric aircraft for regional flights.

Fuel efficiency through innovative engineering

Elsewhere, Delta strengthens its collaboration with Airbus, testing a flying technique called fello'fly, which is inspired by migrating geese.

This method involves a pair of aircraft flying together, where one creates an uplift that can improve the fuel efficiency of the other. According to Airbus, this practice could reduce fuel consumption by 5% on long-haul flights.

Delta also adds MicroTau, an Australian aerospace technology company, to its Sustainable Skies Lab. MicroTau creates an external cladding for planes that mimics shark skin, which the startup claims reduces drag and saves fuel.

The technology can be applied to an aircraft's fuselage, wings and tail and may improve fuel efficiency by up to 4%.

Delta is on track to increase its usage of SAF by 50% compared to the previous year. In 2025, the carrier collaborates with Shell Aviation, Montana Renewables and the Port of Portland on a project that sees the first commercial-scale delivery of SAF to an airport, Portland International Airport.

According to Airbus, SAF can reduce an airline’s emissions by up to 80%.

One of Delta’s primary goals for the year is to procure more than 35 sustainable aircraft. On average, these new planes are over 25% more fuel-efficient per seat mile than the aircraft Delta has retired since 2019.

The airline also rolls out a new range of paper cups across its entire operation, replacing plastic cups on all flights.

title: A first look at the CAA's UK Aviation Environmental Review 2025 - Burges Salmon
description:
As we explained in our previous article in September 2025, the CAA is responsible for implementing the UK’s environmental reporting obligations, which it does through publishing the Aviation Environmental Review (the “AER”).
Read on below for our brief overview of CAP 3198 and what it can tell us about the state of UK aviation.
CAP 3198 confirms that 2019 was the peak year for UK aviation in terms of flight numbers and CO2 emissions.
The AER therefore uses 2019 aviation data as its benchmark for measuring performance.
In 2024, emissions from UK flights grew faster than the number of flights.
text:
As we explained in our previous article in September 2025, the CAA is responsible for implementing the UK’s environmental reporting obligations, which it does through publishing the Aviation Environmental Review (the “AER”). In our previous article, we provided an overview of the CAA’s new approach towards the AER; now, just a few months later, we have the first example of how the CAA has put this approach into practice with the publication of its latest AER using data from up until 2024.

Read on below for our brief overview of CAP 3198 and what it can tell us about the state of UK aviation.

What is the aim of environmental reporting, and how does the AER help achieve it?

As a carbon-intensive industry, aviation plays a crucial role in the UK’s efforts to meet its international environmental commitments. As we recognised in September, the AER provides an important tool for monitoring the industry’s performance with regard to the UK’s environmental objectives and for providing industry stakeholders with usable and detailed data.

What was the direction of travel in 2024?

CAP 3198 confirms that 2019 was the peak year for UK aviation in terms of flight numbers and CO2 emissions. The AER therefore uses 2019 aviation data as its benchmark for measuring performance. CAP 3198 also makes it clear that, if Net Zero is to be achieved by 2050, the baseline levels from 2019 cannot be exceeded.

In terms of greenhouse gas emissions, noise pollution and air quality, road transport remains the largest contributor in the UK; for instance, 97% of greenhouse gas emissions are generated by road transport. Domestic civil aviation is, comparatively, a much smaller contributor at only 1%. However, emissions and pollution from road transport have fallen significantly overall. For example, from 2005 to 2023, emissions from passenger cars reduced by 23% despite the number of miles travelled increasing. A similar trend has been observed in the rail sector.

This is not the case for aviation. In 2024, emissions from UK flights grew faster than the number of flights. Accordingly, aviation is on track to become one of the highest-emitting sectors in the UK as other modes of transport decarbonise more quickly.

What about sustainable fuel?

Despite being one of the key areas identified in CAP 3153 for future reporting, the report does not include data on Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF). This is unsurprising given the historic nature of the data considered and accounting for the fact that the UK’s SAF Mandate has only recently come into force (see our overview of the SAF Mandate regime here). We can expect that it will take some time for the impact of SAF to filter through, and that the next edition of the AER will include more data on this point.

What does it mean for airlines?

The report uses a combination of pre-existing data sources and newly developed databases to analyse the emissions of aircraft departing the UK. The new database has greater accuracy by using the time spent actually in the air by each aircraft, rather than estimates, to measure emissions.

This allows the AER to provide more granular detail on aviation’s environmental impact. This includes greater transparency as to the relative environmental impacts of domestic and short-haul flights on the one hand, and medium-to-long-haul flights on the other. For example, the report confirms that while ultra-short and short-haul flights of under 1,500km account for 63% of all flights in the UK, they only account for 17% of total emissions. By contrast, long-haul flights are responsible for generating 63% of all emissions but represent the smallest proportion of flights in the UK (11%) overall.

It is possible that greater awareness in this area may lead to shifts in passenger behaviour and increased pressure for investment in more sustainable aircraft types and SAF. However, it is also possible that the increased transparency provided by the AER will provide new opportunities for airlines to strategically differentiate themselves in the market by improving resource efficiency and demonstrating leadership in sustainability.

What does it mean for airports?

The report includes detailed findings on air quality (broken down into NOx, SO2, PM2.5 and NMVOCS) and noise pollution around airports, which are individually named.

The results of this analysis come as no surprise. They indicate that flights from the busiest 10 airports across the UK generate more than 95% of all emissions, with Heathrow alone generating more emissions than the other top 10 airports combined.

There is positive news, however: while air traffic has not quite regained 2019 levels (94%), the level of noise pollution has actually fallen at a faster rate, leaving fewer people exposed to daytime aviation noise in 2024. Additionally, the level of SO2 emissions recorded across UK airports in 2023 was 67% lower than in 2019.

That notwithstanding, the air quality data reported in the AER suggests that other sectors are decarbonising more quickly than aviation. This may lead to increased scrutiny for the sector.

Next steps

The CAA is required to publish an AER at least every three years. We can therefore expect the next edition to be published by no later than December 2028.

It will be interesting to see what story the next installment of data analysis tells us about the progress made by the industry following developments including the UK SAF Mandate, the increasing adoption of more fuel-efficient aircraft and the ongoing airspace modernisation programme. It will also be interesting to monitor whether the AER framework will account for other decarbonisation improvements across the sector, including the impact of the CAA's ongoing Hydrogen Challenge. This aims to increase sustainability by preparing UK aviation for the adoption of hydrogen as a zero-carbon fuel, both for use by new aircraft types (primarily on domestic regional routes) and within airport infrastructure.

This article was written by Patrick Bettle and Beata Kolodziej.

title: Air France KLM Martinair Cargo & DHL: Pioneering Sustainable Aviation Fuel Collaboration
description:
As reported by Air France KLM Martinair Cargo (AFKLMP Cargo) and DHL Global Forwarding (DHL), the two companies have forged a new strategic alliance aimed at promoting Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) usage and expediting the decarbonization of air freight.
The collaboration sets an ambitious target for 2025, aiming to cut down emissions by 35,000 tonnes of CO₂-equivalent.
This latest agreement marks AFKLMP Cargo’s most significant annual SAF initiative yet, underscoring both organizations’ dedication to fostering a shift towards sustainable aviation practices.
Since launching its customer-focused SAF initiatives in 2020, AFKLMP Cargo has taken significant strides in this area.
Meanwhile, DHL has integrated SAF into its GoGreen Plus service as a key component of its environmental objectives.
text:
As reported by Air France KLM Martinair Cargo (AFKLMP Cargo) and DHL Global Forwarding (DHL), the two companies have forged a new strategic alliance aimed at promoting Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) usage and expediting the decarbonization of air freight.

This partnership builds on their previous agreement from 2022 to 2024, culminating in a fresh three-year framework that spans from 2025 to 2027.

The collaboration sets an ambitious target for 2025, aiming to cut down emissions by 35,000 tonnes of CO₂-equivalent. This latest agreement marks AFKLMP Cargo’s most significant annual SAF initiative yet, underscoring both organizations’ dedication to fostering a shift towards sustainable aviation practices.

The specifics regarding additional SAF volumes and corresponding emission reductions for the years 2026 and 2027 will be established as the partnership evolves.

Since launching its customer-focused SAF initiatives in 2020, AFKLMP Cargo has taken significant strides in this area. Meanwhile, DHL has integrated SAF into its GoGreen Plus service as a key component of its environmental objectives. Together, these companies leverage their extensive expertise and shared vision to promote low-carbon fuel adoption effectively. Their renewed contract is built upon prior success where DHL achieved a reduction of nearly 77,600 tons of CO₂-equivalent during their last three-year collaboration.

This joint effort not only aids customers in making tangible advancements toward science-based carbon reduction goals but also highlights the importance of sustained partnerships in propelling the aviation sector towards greener solutions.

title: MB Energy Expands Aviation Fuel Supply to Airlines at Copenhagen Airport | TankTerminals
description:
December 18, 2025 [Storage Terminals Magazine]- MB Energy has commenced the supply of jet fuel and HEFA SPK Blend, commonly referred to as Sustainable Aviation Fuel, to airlines operating at Copenhagen Airport in Denmark.
To enable fuel supply at Copenhagen Airport, MB Energy has invested in the airport’s fuel infrastructure, securing access to support reliable and efficient operations for its aviation customers.
The investment reflects the company’s long-term commitment to strengthening aviation fuel supply chains in Denmark and across Europe.
In addition to conventional jet fuel, MB Energy will supply SAF at Copenhagen Airport, reinforcing the company’s commitment to advancing more sustainable solutions for aviation.
By offering alternatives to traditional aviation fuels, MB Energy aims to support airlines in reducing the environmental impact of their operations.
text:
December 18, 2025 [Storage Terminals Magazine]- MB Energy has commenced the supply of jet fuel and HEFA SPK Blend, commonly referred to as Sustainable Aviation Fuel, to airlines operating at Copenhagen Airport in Denmark. The SAF supplied contributes to reducing carbon dioxide emissions over its life cycle. This development marks MB Energy’s expansion into the Danish aviation market, adding Copenhagen Airport to the company’s growing network of airport locations already served across Germany, the UK and Norway.

To enable fuel supply at Copenhagen Airport, MB Energy has invested in the airport’s fuel infrastructure, securing access to support reliable and efficient operations for its aviation customers. The investment reflects the company’s long-term commitment to strengthening aviation fuel supply chains in Denmark and across Europe.

Simon Weiss, head of aviation at MB Energy, said the move underscores the company’s dedication to supporting the aviation sector’s evolving needs. He noted that MB Energy looks forward to continuing its work in aviation by collaborating closely with customers and partners to support both current operations and the transition toward more sustainable air travel.

In addition to conventional jet fuel, MB Energy will supply SAF at Copenhagen Airport, reinforcing the company’s commitment to advancing more sustainable solutions for aviation. By offering alternatives to traditional aviation fuels, MB Energy aims to support airlines in reducing the environmental impact of their operations.

MB Energy provides tailored energy solutions designed to support customers’ decarbonisation journeys. The company offers a broad and flexible product portfolio that serves the conventional fuel market while actively enabling routes to market for lower-carbon fuel solutions. Its strategic focus is on growing the business in hard-to-electrify sectors such as aviation, leveraging core strengths in sourcing, storage, handling and distribution of liquid fuels.

title: SWISS signs long-term offtake agreement for solar jet fuel from Synhelion - SolarPACES
description:
Press Release Zurich, December 16, 2025 Swiss International Air Lines (SWISS) and Swiss cleantech company Synhelion have signed a long-term offtake agreement for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
From 2027, SWISS will purchase at least 200 tons of solar jet fuel from Synhelion annually, pioneering the use of this innovative fuel in civil aviation.
Thus, Synhelion directly replaces fossil crude oil with sustainable syncrude, without the need for any adjustments to the existing infrastructure.
First delivery already completed In July 2025, SWISS became the first airline in the world to use solar fuel from Synhelion in regular flight operations.
Synhelion produces first solar syngas in Wood’s industrial-scale reforming reactor CEMEX and Synhelion ace the First “Hot Solar” Cement Trial At Synhelion, Solar Jet Fuels Get Ready for Take-off
text:
Press Release Zurich, December 16, 2025

Swiss International Air Lines (SWISS) and Swiss cleantech company Synhelion have signed a long-term offtake agreement for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). From 2027, SWISS will purchase at least 200 tons of solar jet fuel from Synhelion annually, pioneering the use of this innovative fuel in civil aviation. The agreement marks an important milestone on the road to more sustainable aviation.

SWISS is the first airline to sign a binding five-year SAF offtake agreement with Synhelion. This marks a pioneering step toward defossilizing aviation. From 2027, Synhelion will produce renewable synthetic crude oil, known as “syncrude”, at its first commercial plant. The syncrude will be processed in an existing refinery together with fossil crude oil and refined into certified Jet-A-1 fuel. Thus, Synhelion directly replaces fossil crude oil with sustainable syncrude, without the need for any adjustments to the existing infrastructure. The fuel will be delivered to the airport via the regular logistics chain and fed into the fuel supply system. Synhelion’s synthetic jet fuel is based on renewable energy and sustainable feedstocks.

A strong signal for sustainable aviation

“The partnership with Synhelion is a significant step for SWISS on the path to decarbonizing our flight operations,” says Jens Fehlinger, CEO of SWISS. “Sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) are a core element of our sustainability strategy. The offtake agreement with Synhelion sends a strong signal for innovation and responsibility in aviation.”

With this offtake agreement, SWISS is actively supporting the scaling of Synhelion’s technology for the production of renewable synthetic fuels as a customer, investor, and strategic partner. This long-term planning certainty enables targeted expansion of production capacity and helps reduce costs over time.

Pioneering partnership

Synhelion also emphasizes the significance of the agreement: “The fact that SWISS, a leading airline, has committed early on to adopt our fuels demonstrates confidence in the market readiness of our technology,” says Philipp Furler, Co-CEO and Co-Founder of Synhelion. “This partnership is a milestone for the commercial market launch of our fuels – and sets a powerful example to other airlines worldwide.”

Expanding the partnership with Kuehne+Nagel

Part of the renewable jet fuel produced by Synhelion will be resold by SWISS to the logistics service provider Kuehne+Nagel. The company will use the sustainable fuel for air freight transportation with Swiss WorldCargo, offering its customers a tangible solution to reduce their carbon footprint in global logistics.

First delivery already completed

In July 2025, SWISS became the first airline in the world to use solar fuel from Synhelion in regular flight operations. Synhelion delivered its first barrel of syncrude from its DAWN plant to a refinery in northern Germany, where the syncrude was processed into certified jet fuel (Jet-A-1) and subsequently fed into the fuel supply system via Hamburg Airport.

How can Synhelion’s solar receiver achieve such high temperatures?

Synhelion produces first solar syngas in Wood’s industrial-scale reforming reactor

CEMEX and Synhelion ace the First “Hot Solar” Cement Trial

At Synhelion, Solar Jet Fuels Get Ready for Take-off

title: From cooking oil to jet fuel: Cathay Pacific shines the spotlight on SAF
description:
The bottle contains used cooking oil, Haas explains, which is one of the raw materials most widely used for producing sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
“And this is SAF,” Haas says, holding up another sealed bottle filled with crystal-clear liquid.
“It’s jet fuel – though most people wouldn’t guess it, since it looks just like water.
And a key part of his job is to accelerate SAF adoption at Cathay Pacific.
SAF attributes are the environmental benefits that result from a specified amount of SAF used to replace conventional jet fuel.
text:
“Do you know what this is, or what this might be – the dirty-looking one?” asks Oliver Haas, the head of sustainability – commercial and innovation at Cathay Pacific, holding up a laboratory bottle filled with dark, murky liquid. The bottle contains used cooking oil, Haas explains, which is one of the raw materials most widely used for producing sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).

“And this is SAF,” Haas says, holding up another sealed bottle filled with crystal-clear liquid. “It’s jet fuel – though most people wouldn’t guess it, since it looks just like water. But it’s incredibly refined and packed with high-performance chemistry.”

“The magic of SAF is that basically you can turn this into this,” Haas says, holding the two bottles side by side. “You can turn a waste product into jet-grade fuel.”

Having been obsessed – in his words – with aircraft since he was five years old, Haas now sits in an office filled with models of them. And a key part of his job is to accelerate SAF adoption at Cathay Pacific.

Advertisement

In addition to used cooking oil, raw materials used to produce SAF include municipal waste, agricultural residue and even carbon dioxide. The chemical properties of SAF are almost identical to those of conventional jet fuel, and both types can be safely combined for use in aircraft.

“The benefit of SAF is that it is a so-called ‘drop-in fuel’,” Haas says. “Today, it has to be blended by up to 50 per cent with jet fuel, and there are various tests happening in the industry to allow 100 per cent of it to be used. But fundamentally, it can be dropped into an existing aircraft.”

Advertisement

While there are other options for powering an aircraft in a more sustainable way, including hydrogen and electricity, “the big challenge in aviation is that it is very difficult to find alternatives that can compete with jet fuel,” Haas says.

While small electric aircraft are under development, Haas points out they are more suited for regional, short-haul routes in markets such as Europe, the United States and Australia. And though hydrogen can fuel larger aircraft, the challenge lies in producing it cleanly and at a scale that makes it viable.

According to technical analysis conducted by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), a United Nations agency, SAF has the greatest potential to reduce carbon emissions produced by air travel.

Advertisement

Haas cites a typical flight from Sydney to Hong Kong as an example: “That is a nine-hour flight, which Cathay Pacific currently flies with aircraft that carry more than 300 passengers. There simply aren’t many options to move that many people over that distance in that time, other than by using liquid fuels.”

While SAF is, for now, the most viable option for airlines to reduce their carbon emissions while maintaining current numbers of flights, it also comes with significant challenges, such as high production costs. And SAF supply is still limited – in 2024, it made up just 0.3 per cent of global jet fuel production, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA), a trade body with 350 member airlines. At these levels, costs will remain high at all points of the SAF supply chain.

Advertisement

Cathay Pacific has launched a new platform that allows passengers to estimate the carbon emissions generated by their flights and make a voluntary contribution to buy SAF attributes. SAF attributes are the environmental benefits that result from a specified amount of SAF used to replace conventional jet fuel.

Each contribution made is used to purchase SAF that is in addition to the airline’s mandated requirement of the percentage of SAF to be mixed into conventional jet fuel. Some countries and trading blocs have now mandated a minimum usage requirement for SAF. The United Kingdom, for instance, has set a SAF usage target of 10 per cent by 2030, while the European Union has set a minimum mandate of 2 per cent this year, to be increased to 70 per cent by 2050.

Eligible members of the Cathay membership programme can earn one Asia Mile for every HK$1 contribution they make to the SAF programme – a special rate offered to passengers to encourage them to take meaningful action and contribute to scaling up the use of SAF.

Advertisement

However, the use of SAF continues to remain a mystery to many people. Haas explains that unlike an electric car, which feels different in the way it sounds, drives and accelerates, SAF is effectively invisible to passengers.

“Even if I put SAF in the aircraft you are sitting in, you don’t have an emotional relationship with that. You can’t touch it. You can’t smell it. You can’t feel it. The whole point of SAF is that it is made to be as close to an equivalent of conventional jet fuel as possible,” he says.

With this in mind, Haas and his team are working on ways to make SAF more relatable to passengers, with most ideas still in their early stages.

Advertisement

No airline can do this alone, and Cathay Pacific’s approach to scaling SAF also includes the Corporate SAF Programme, established in 2022 for its corporate customers. It allows them to purchase SAF attributes with the airline and supports companies in reducing indirect emissions from business trips, while helping the airline to scale SAF usage.

Recently, the airline also announced its participation – as a founding investor – in a new fund, alongside several Oneworld alliance members and Breakthrough Energy Ventures (BEV), an investment firm founded by Bill Gates that funds climate technology. The Oneworld BEV Fund will address difficulties around the production and cost of SAF, and invest in new technology to that end. Cathay Pacific also announced a joint investment agreement with Airbus, valued at HK$545 million (US$70 million), to drive the development of SAF production globally.

And at its home base, Cathay Pacific has co-initiated the Hong Kong Sustainable Aviation Fuel Coalition, working with partners to support policy and infrastructure development that will facilitate the use of SAF at Hong Kong International Airport.

Advertisement

However, it is the need to increase general awareness of SAF that Haas says keeps him awake at night and gets him up in the morning.

“Aviation connects people, culture and ideas, and I want to see more of that happen,” he says. “And as individual fliers, we carry a responsibility when we fly. The future of aviation is about continuing to make global travel possible, not just for ourselves, but for others and other generations too.”

Advertisement

title: Egypt enters the sustainable aviation fuel race
description:
Egypt has taken a decisive step toward decarbonizing one of the hardest-to-abate sectors—aviation—by signing its first production license agreement for a sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) project.
Why sustainable aviation fuel matters now Aviation accounts for a growing share of global emissions, and airlines face mounting pressure from regulators, investors, and customers to cut carbon intensity.
Economic returns beyond emissions reduction While climate benefits are central, the SAF project has broader economic implications: 1.
Job creation and skills transfer SAF production requires specialized chemical, engineering, and operational expertise, strengthening Egypt’s industrial skill base.
Rather than viewing decarbonization as a threat, Egypt’s energy authorities are positioning traditional institutions as drivers of the transition, using existing infrastructure, expertise, and partnerships to enter new markets.
text:
Egypt has taken a decisive step toward decarbonizing one of the hardest-to-abate sectors—aviation—by signing its first production license agreement for a sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) project. The agreement, witnessed by the minister of petroleum and mineral resources, marks a structural shift in how Egypt’s energy and petrochemical sectors approach climate goals, industrial value creation, and export-oriented growth.

Unlike pilot programs or memoranda of understanding, this deal authorizes actual production, signaling that SAF is moving from concept to infrastructure in Egypt.

Why sustainable aviation fuel matters now

Aviation accounts for a growing share of global emissions, and airlines face mounting pressure from regulators, investors, and customers to cut carbon intensity. SAF has emerged as the most viable near-term solution, as it can be blended with conventional jet fuel without requiring new aircraft or airport infrastructure.

For Egypt, SAF is strategically attractive for three reasons:

Immediate emissions impact without disrupting aviation operations

Alignment with international climate and aviation standards, particularly in Europe

Creation of a high-value green fuel export, not just domestic substitution

By entering SAF production early, Egypt positions itself within a global supply chain that is still capacity-constrained but rapidly expanding.

What the Alexandria project will deliver

The SAF facility will be built in Alexandria and designed to convert used cooking oil into aviation-grade fuel. This choice of feedstock is economically and environmentally significant.

Key project characteristics include:

Annual production capacity: up to 120,000 tons

Feedstock: waste oils, primarily used cooking oil

Estimated emissions reduction: around 400,000 tons of CO₂ per year

From an industrial standpoint, the project does more than produce cleaner fuel—it upgrades waste into a premium energy product, reinforcing circular-economy principles while reducing reliance on virgin fossil inputs.

Technology as the critical enabler

At the heart of the project is advanced hydrotreating technology capable of converting waste oils into fuel that meets international aviation specifications. Conversion rates of up to 80 percent significantly improve project economics, making SAF more competitive against conventional jet fuel.

This matters because SAF’s biggest challenge globally is cost. Higher conversion efficiency directly reduces unit costs and strengthens the business case for scaling production.

By adopting proven global technology platforms rather than experimental solutions, Egypt reduces execution risk and accelerates time to market.

Economic returns beyond emissions reduction

While climate benefits are central, the SAF project has broader economic implications:

1. Value-added manufacturing

Instead of exporting raw hydrocarbons or low-margin products, Egypt is moving into advanced fuel processing with higher margins and technical complexity.

2. Export potential

European airlines and airports are under regulatory pressure to increase SAF usage. Egypt’s geographic proximity gives it a logistics advantage in serving Mediterranean and European markets.

3. Job creation and skills transfer

SAF production requires specialized chemical, engineering, and operational expertise, strengthening Egypt’s industrial skill base.

4. Waste management benefits

Scaling used cooking oil collection formalizes waste streams that are often informal or underutilized, creating new micro-economies around collection and logistics.

A signal to investors and global partners

Beyond the plant itself, the agreement sends a broader message: Egypt is open to commercial-scale green energy investments, not just renewables like solar and wind, but also low-carbon fuels that serve global industries.

This diversification matters. As countries compete for climate-aligned capital, projects that combine technology, exports, and measurable emissions reduction are increasingly favored by international investors and development institutions.

SAF as part of Egypt’s energy transition strategy

The petroleum sector’s involvement is particularly notable. Rather than viewing decarbonization as a threat, Egypt’s energy authorities are positioning traditional institutions as drivers of the transition, using existing infrastructure, expertise, and partnerships to enter new markets.

SAF fits neatly into this approach:

It leverages petrochemical know-how

It supports national climate commitments

It preserves Egypt’s relevance in a lower-carbon global energy system

A first step with long-term implications

While one plant will not transform aviation overnight, this agreement establishes a blueprint. If successful, it can be replicated, expanded, and integrated into a broader ecosystem of green fuels, including marine fuels and synthetic alternatives.

title: Private jet sustainability, regulations key issue for high-profile flyers
description:
The change in the U.S. political climate is not sidetracking private jet sustainability initiatives or affecting the need for high-profile private jet users to stay focused on the issue.
